instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2610: What is 820-2610? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> LFXP2-8E5MGC  replacable with LFXP2-8E5MGCAD2?
threads.message: Will LFXP2-8E5MGCAD2 work on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> LFXP2-8E5MGC  replacable with LFXP2-8E5MGCAD2?
threads.message: No idea, but these have firmware. Normally they do not die, just need reflow/reball. You can probably get away with using one from a 15" 2009 board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> LFXP2-8E5MGC  replacable with LFXP2-8E5MGCAD2?
threads.message: I reballed the original but it seemed to have gotten worse image quality. Maybe the balls werent even. I figured i damaged it with too much heat. I shall see about a 2009 board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> LFXP2-8E5MGC  replacable with LFXP2-8E5MGCAD2?
threads.message: Just bad reball is more likely or a knocked off resistor around the MUX.
